translated: Verses of the Elders
The Section with Sixteen Groups
The First Chapter
Udāyī
A human being, a fully awakened one,
self-controlled, concentrated,
practicing the path of brahmā,
delighting in the stilling of mind.
The one whom humans worship,
who has gone beyond all things,
the gods also worship him,
so I have heard from the perfected one.

analyzed: sabba sayojana atīta  vanā nibbanam āgata
translated: Beyond all fetters,🔽gone to the forest, attained to peace,
delighting in renunciation, free from sensual pleasures,
like a rock unshaken.
He is truly a radiant nāga,
like the Himalayas, the king of mountains,
among all the names of nāgas,
the name “Truthful” is unsurpassed.
I will praise the nāga for you,
for he does not commit offenses.
Gentleness and harmlessness
are his two nāga feet.
Mindfulness and clear comprehension
are his two other nāga feet.
The great nāga has faith for his trunk,
equanimity for his tusks.
Mindfulness is his neck, wisdom his head,
investigation and reflection on the Dhamma.
Dwelling in the womb of the Dhamma,
seclusion is his tail.
He is a meditator, one who breathes serenely,

original: ajjhattaṁ susamāhito;🔽Gacchaṁ samāhito nāgo,🔽ṭhito nāgo samāhito.
analyzed: ajjhattam su samāhitaḥ  gaccham samāhitaḥ nāgaḥ  ṭhitaḥ nāgaḥ samāhitaḥ
translated: well-composed within.🔽The elephant is composed when walking,🔽the elephant is composed when standing.
The elephant is composed when lying down,
the elephant is composed when sitting.
The elephant is restrained in every way:
this is the perfection of the elephant.
He eats what is blameless,
not what is blameful.
Having received food and clothing,
he avoids hoarding.🔽He cuts off all bonds,

analyzed: sa yojanam aṇum  sabbam chetvāna bandhana
translated: whether gross or fine,
and wherever he goes
he goes without concern.

analyzed: yathā api udake jāta  puṇḍarīkam pavaḍḍhati
translated: Just as a lotus, born in the water,🔽grows up in the water without touching it,
and is unsoiled by it,
fragrant and lovely,
so the Buddha, born in the world,
lives in the world without clinging to the world,
unsoiled by the world,
like a lotus by the water.
A great fire burns
when it gets fuel,
but when there is no fuel it is said to be extinguished.
This is the explanation of the meaning
of the simile taught by the wise.
The great elephants will understand.

analyzed: nāgam nāgena desita  vīta rāgaḥ vīta dosaḥ  vīta mohaḥ anāsavaḥ
translated: The elephant by the elephant, the one without attachment, the one without aversion,
The one without delusion, the one without defilements,🔽The elephant gave up his body,
The one without defilements will attain final Nibbāna.”
… the elder Udāyī …
The sixteenth collection is finished.🔽Here is the summary:
Koṇḍañña and Udāyī,
two elders with great spiritual powers,
In the sixteenth collection,
there are thirty-two verses.
